diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can explain the malar rash, pleural effusion, fever, and, in rare cases, psychosis due to CNS involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by rash and muscle weakness, can sometimes present with systemic features like fever. Follicular hyperkeratosis is less common but can occur due to skin involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Though more rare in developed countries and among adults, it can cause fever, rash, and in severe cases, carditis leading to pleural effusion. The association with psychosis is more coincidental, related to Sydenham's chorea.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by fever, rash, and pleural effusion among other symptoms, but psychosis and follicular hyperkeratosis are not common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Disseminated Gonococcal Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause a rash and fever, and in rare cases, pleural effusion. Psychosis and follicular hyperkeratosis are not typically seen.

diagnoses.name: Viral Exanthemas
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can lead to fever, rashes, and in more severe systemic cases, pleural effusion. Psychosis is rare but can occur in severe systemic infections or post-infectiously.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: This disease can affect multiple organ systems leading to fever, rash, and pleural effusions. Neurosarcoidosis can potentially lead to psychiatric manifestations but is rare.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: With its effect on the immune system, HIV can present with fever, rashes (including malar rash in rare situations), pleural effusion as part of a secondary infection, and in advanced cases, can lead to neurological and psychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can present with fever, rash, pleural effusion, and in rare cases, skin changes including follicular hyperkeratosis. CNS involvement could theoretically contribute to psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Commonly known for causing erythema infectiosum in children, it can also affect adults, leading to fever, rash, and arthropathy. Pleural effusion is rare but can happen. Psychosis and follicular hyperkeratosis are not typically associated.

diagnoses: Infectious Diseases (Viral, Bacterial, Parasitic infections causing reactive arthritis)
Drug-induced (e.g., due to procainamide, hydralazine, isoniazid)

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.reasoning: Frequent waking could be a sign of high blood pressure, as can flushing. Atherosclerosis is a common consequence of long-term hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.reasoning: Frequent waking is a common symptom of sleep apnea. Patients with sleep apnea often have or are at risk for atherosclerosis due to associated comorbidities like hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Blepharospasm may be an early sign of Parkinson’s Disease, as well as sleep disturbances like frequent waking.

diagnoses.name: Rosacea
diagnoses.reasoning: Flushing is a hallmark of rosacea, which can also cause eye symptoms potentially linked to blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Flushing and frequent waking (due to discomfort or cardiac symptoms) may be symptoms. The condition also relates to vascular abnormalities, which could indirectly relate to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Tobacco or Alcohol Use Disorder
diagnoses.reasoning: Both habits are risk factors for atherosclerosis and leukoplakia. They can also disrupt sleep patterns, leading to frequent waking.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperthyroidism can cause symptoms like flushing and frequent waking. It can also accelerate the development of atherosclerosis due to an increased metabolic rate.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Patients with anxiety can experience frequent waking and flushing. Anxiety might also worsen blepharospasm due to increased stress.

diagnoses.name: Primary Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This autoimmune disorder can cause dry eyes, potentially leading to blepharospasm. Sleep disturbances are also common due to discomfort from dryness.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare tumor can cause flushing and frequent waking due to episodes of hypertension. It indirectly could accelerate atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of blood disorders characterized by high numbers of eosinophils in the blood and tissues, which can cause organ damage. Symptoms can vary significantly and may include skin rashes, alopecia, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can manifest in skin hyperelasticity, joint hypermobility, and sometimes vision problems due to its effect on connective tissue.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can result in symptoms across the body, including alopecia, angioedema-like swelling, and eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that causes inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis). This inflammation can lead to angioedema, eosinophilia, and in later stages, peripheral neuropathy that might affect vision focus.

diagnoses.name: Gleich's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disease characterized by episodic angioedema, weight gain, fever, and marked eosinophilia. It is considered a variant of hypereosinophilic syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder that results in recurrent attacks of severe swelling. The swelling can occur in the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway. Joint hypermobility is not directly associated but occurs in some affected individuals.

diagnoses.name: Loeffler's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A transient respiratory illness associated with blood eosinophilia and characterized by paroxysmal cough, dyspnea, and inflitrates on chest x-ray. It does not typically present with alopecia or difficulty focusing vision but falls under eosinophilic disorders.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that results in an increased level of circulating red blood cells. It can indirectly cause angioedema through increased blood volume and pressure, and itching but is less commonly associated with eosinophilia, alopecia, or hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder primarily affecting exocrine glands including those producing tears and saliva, leading to dry eyes and mouth. Systemic manifestations can include joint pain and skin rashes, and in rare instances, alopecia and organ involvement with eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially leading to a variety of symptoms, including fatigue, difficulty focusing, and fertility issues.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). Diabetes can lead to neuropathy and has been linked with sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system that can lead to fatigue, lack of concentration, vision problems, and neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age, which could cause infertility and has been associated with sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A serious sleep disorder where breathing repeatedly stops and starts, which can lead to daytime fatigue and difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Obesity
diagnoses.description: Excessive fat accumulation that presents a risk to health, potentially leading to sleep apnea, infertility, and has been linked with sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the thyroid gland, which regulates numerous metabolic processes throughout the body. Disorders can lead to symptoms like difficulty concentrating and vision issues.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological problems, which might include neuropathies and difficulties with concentration.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A common but serious mood disorder. It causes severe symptoms that affect how you feel, think, and handle daily activities. It can manifest as difficulty concentrating, fatigue, and more.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reactions
diagnoses.description: An allergy occurs when the body's immune system reacts to substances (allergens) that are generally harmless to most people, such as pollen, food, or dust mites. The symptoms can include irritated eyes, skin reactions including pruritus (itching), and respiratory issues.

diagnoses.name: Atopic dermatitis (Eczema)
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Atopic dermatitis is long-lasting (chronic) and tends to flare periodically. It may be accompanied by asthma or hay fever.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it. The rash isn't contagious or life-threatening but can be very uncomfortable. Substances causing the reaction can include soaps, cosmetics, fragrances, jewelry, and plants.

diagnoses.name: Scabies
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious skin infestation caused by a tiny, burrowing mite. It causes intense itching that's often worse at night, along with a pimple-like rash. It can affect various parts of the body, including areas around the waist, buttocks, and thighs, potentially leading to secondary infections due to scratching.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells, which provide oxygen to body tissues. Symptoms can include fatigue and physical sensitivity, alongside other symptoms like irritability and frequent waking due to discomfort or restless leg syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Liver disease
diagnoses.description: Liver problems can affect your body's ability to filter toxins, leading to symptoms such as migratory pruritus (itching without a clear rash, particularly common in cholestasis), irritated eyes, and other systemic symptoms. Liver disease symptoms can vary widely, including fatigue, nausea, and more.

diagnoses.name: Chronic kidney disease
diagnoses.description: As kidney function declines, waste products can build up in the blood, causing a variety of symptoms including nausea, fatigue, sleep problems (such as frequent waking), and pruritus. Hemorrhoids may not be directly linked but can occur or worsen due to associated constipation or straining.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid disorders
diagnoses.description: Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can cause a variety of symptoms, including sensitivities to temperature, fatigue, irritability, and skin changes. Thyroid dysfunction can indirectly contribute to sleep disturbances and might aggravate or be associated with other symptoms such as hemorrhoids due to systemic effects on metabolism and circulation.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: High blood sugar levels over a long period can cause a broad array of symptoms, including frequent urination (which can disrupt sleep), increased thirst, weight loss, and fatigue. Skin complications like bacterial and fungal infections can result in pruritus. Hemorrhoids may be exacerbated by increased straining due to constipation, a common complaint among those with diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Psychological conditions
diagnoses.description: Stress, anxiety, and depression can manifest physically and may exacerbate or mimic physical symptoms like digestive issues leading to hemorrhoids, disrupted sleep patterns, and sensitivity to physical stimuli. Itching or pruritus can be a psychosomatic symptom.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Certain deficiencies, notably vitamin B12, zinc, and vitamin C, can cause symptoms like dysgeusia (altered taste), ulcers, periodontal disease, decreased appetite, and in some cases, changes in smell (dysosmia).

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears, leading to dry mouth, gum disease, ulcers, altered taste, and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder where stomach acid irritates the food pipe lining, potentially causing dysgeusia, decreased appetite, and could indirectly affect oral health.

diagnoses.name: Oral and Pharyngeal Cancers
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the mouth or throat can lead to symptoms such as ulcers, periodontal disease, and changes in taste. Decreased appetite can be a direct result of the discomfort caused by these cancers.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV and AIDS can cause a wide array of symptoms, including periodontal disease, ulcers, dysgeusia, and decreased appetite, due to the immune system's decreased ability to fight off infections.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: Diabetes, especially when uncontrolled, can lead to periodontal disease, decrease in appetite, and a susceptibility to infections, which may result in oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Pellagra
diagnoses.description: Caused by a deficiency of niacin (Vitamin B3), pellagra leads to dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and can cause mouth ulcers, periodontal disease, and changes in taste or smell.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory bowel disease that can cause mouth ulcers as one of its many symptoms, alongside changes in taste and decreased appetite due to gastrointestinal distress.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A lack of sufficient zinc can manifest as decreased appetite, dysgeusia, and might contribute to periodontal disease due to its role in cell growth and repair.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common condition where a lack of iron in the body leads to anemia, which can cause mouth ulcers, altered taste, and a reduction in appetite among its symptoms.

diagnoses: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (as a primary diagnosis with potential psychosomatic manifestations)
Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Urinary tract infection (complicated with severe sepsis)
Anxiety or panic attacks inducing hyperventilation
Gastrointestinal disorders causing vomiting and potential dehydration leading to syncope
Allergic reaction to food or medications
Drug reaction (including antibiotics, NSAIDs, and chemotherapeutic agents)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe throbbing and pulsating pain on one side of the head. The aura phase includes symptoms such as visual disturbances (scintillation), sensory changes, and speech or language abnormalities (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, aphasia, and can sometimes involve nausea or vomiting, particularly in hemorrhagic strokes.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it mimics stroke-like symptoms including aphasia, headaches, and visual disturbances but usually resolves within minutes to hours without permanent brain damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms such as headaches, nausea, vomiting, aphasia, and visual disturbances depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It can present with aphasia and headache during or after seizures.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. Symptoms can include headache, nausea, and vomiting, along with a stiff neck, and in severe cases, altered mental status and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain tissue. It's often caused by a viral infection, and symptoms can include headache, nausea, vomiting, seizures, problems with speech or hearing (aphasia), and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis
diagnoses.description: A rare form of stroke that occurs when a blood clot forms in the brain's venous sinuses. This prevents blood from draining out of the brain, leading to increased intracranial pressure, which can cause headaches, nausea and vomiting, visual disturbances, and possibly aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include vision problems, balance issues, dizziness, and in some cases, speech disturbances such as aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES)
diagnoses.description: A syndrome that can be caused by various conditions, leading to symptoms such as headache, seizures, visual disturbances, and in more severe cases, nausea and aphasia. It is characterized by white matter changes on imaging studies.

diagnoses: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) with secondary rheumatological manifestations
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Severe acute viral infections (e.g., dengue fever, Ebola)
Schizophrenia (in the context of comorbidity with autoimmune disorders)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., Hepatitis B related Polyarteritis Nodosa)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if unrelated to other symptoms)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
